Bash(gh issue create --title "Assuming context manager drops pre-existing global assumptions on exit" --body "$\(cat <<''EOF''
## Summary

The `Assuming` context manager always removes conditions on exit, which can inadvertently drop pre-existing global assumptions that were set before entering the context.

## Location

`assumptions.py` \(line 59\)

## Problem

When `Assuming` exits, it unconditionally removes all conditions it was managing, but it doesn''t track which conditions were **newly added** versus which were **already present**. This means:

```python
# Pre-existing assumption
assume\(x > 0\)

with Assuming\(y > 0\):
    # both x > 0 and y > 0 active
    pass

# x > 0 may be dropped!
```

## Suggested Fix

Track which conditions were newly added during `__enter__` and only remove those specific conditions during `__exit__`, preserving any pre-existing global assumptions.

## Severity

High - Silent correctness issue that can lead to wrong results in downstream computations.
EOF
\)")
